dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM -вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Tiny golden wheels and gears turning lazily upon metal rods. Mechanic Small and intricate. Glittering in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: The gears are turning within an ANTIQUE DESK CLOCK sitting on a book sh pendulum swinging back and forth behind the glass housing. The room is barren except for a pair of open suitcases and a bed that stripped. Sitting on the mattress is ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart and clever. Dressed in a graduation gown and staring out the seems to be lost in thought, immobile, until the bedroom door swings

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR LEVIN,
dialogues.text: aged seventeen and wearing a suit and tie, steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: Dad says we gotta get moving. We're late.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: You're sitting on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Thanks for clearing that up. I'll be right down. He steps out. Julia takes a framed picture out of her suitcase -- a candid shot of he standing with her MOTHER, forties, a healthy and vibrant woman. JULIA (cont'd) Sure do miss you. Above her, a CEILING FAN rotates. Creating a soft HUMMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia walks out of the building where her father, GUY LEVIN, an older man face, waits. Connor is checking his reflection in the car windo his tie, fussing with his hair.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: All set. I packed up everything. (remembering) Oh, except Mom's clock -- I think there's something wrong with it. I telling the right time.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I'll get it fixed. Probably just needs a few new parts. Guy smiles at Julia for a moment. Very warmly. GUY (cont'd) You look just like your mother. Julia is momentarily uncomfortable. But she recovers, father on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: We'll be late.

dialogues.speaker: OF CALIFORNIA, LOS ANGELES
dialogues.text: smiles and kisses her  Students dressed in graduation caps and gowns are gathered on the grounds. Julia stands by herself, taking pictures with a professional Nikon camera the camera upon ...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY ALBA, 22,
dialogues.text: beautiful and sexy. Very particular and demanding. She sm perfectly as Julia snaps the picture. But her boyfriend, SAM BURNSIDE, cute mischievous, sporting pink hair and loud clothes, makes a face. Winding her film, Julia searches a moment, then smiles. Raising her c she snaps a picture of ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL LOOMIS
dialogues.text: Early twenties. Dark hair. Strapping and perfectly handsome. He wears a b striped tie with his starched white shirt and graduation gown.  He kisses her. Passionate and gentle.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You packed up?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Ready to move in. I'll be storing some of the stuff you've already got. CD player. Microwave.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (suggestively) Bed. Julia smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Med School doesn't start until August. At least not for the freshmen got plenty of time to see Europe, take the car trip up north ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I hope it won't be a drag. There's a lot of stuff to move out of my mothe

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Our friends will be there. It'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I hope so.  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Tense.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Would it help if I massaged your breasts?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Because it would help me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (stifling laughter) Maybe later. The students start forming into lines. JULIA (cont'd) Hey, I saw your Mom and kid sister. Where's your Dad? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But it's your  graduation. Paul shrugs again. A brief sting of hurt on his face.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wasn't a good enough reason in High School either. Paul looks away. Julia knows how painful this is and to diminish it. Julia smiles and runs her finger across his tie knot.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I like your tie. UCLA colors.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: won't insult him by trying  School spirit. I am a Bruin. The lines start moving towards the stadium. Hundreds of CHEERS rise up fr graduating students. As she walks, a sound draws Julia's attention. Standing on the lawn is a more than four years-old, SOBBING and clinging to his mother's legs Julia stops walking as she gazes at the child. The line comes to a ha her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (cont'd) Julia. We can't graduate unless you move.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Sorry.  She stalks walking again. Paul puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: A big, traditional house nestled in the hills. PARENTS and gradu STUDENTS exchange polite conversation in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Sitting between a pair of open french doors is "the gang" consisting of J and Terry and Sam. They throw around conversation, ignoring the par

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It's secluded? Nobody said anything to me about the cabin being secluded

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I said it was a cabin in the woods. I thought seclusion was a given.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I'm no good out in the woods. You know what lives in the woods? Animals t Animals that bite.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So avoid the animals.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I really appreciate you guys helping me. I couldn't move everythin

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey, it's our last chance to be together. Terry and I are excited.  (turns) Aren't we, Ter? She's not excited.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Can I bring my cotton bedsheets to the cabin? If I try to sleep in anyth cotton, I get hives.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Whatever makes you happy. Sam grabs a large drawing pad from the steps. He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Speaking of which, I've got your graduation gift. As specified.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Let's see. Sam holds up a sketch of Clark Kent changing to Superman.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Like it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It's great. Thanks Sam. Paul checks out the drawing. His nose crinkles.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Superman? Why'd you want a drawing of Superman?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: He's very attractive.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (staring) You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He's not even real.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I think most women tend to wonder if Superman is super in every way.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You see. There goes your argument.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) But Spiderman has a nice ass. Off everyone's

dialogues.speaker: LOOK --
dialogues.text: TERRY (cont'd)  What?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Julia finishes washing her hands. Dries them. Grabbing her camera and th Julia opens the bathroom door ...

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: ++. and freezes. Standing within an open bedroom is ...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT.
dialogues.text: Another college graduate. Tan and attractive. Dressed exactly like Paul - white shirt, gold and blue striped tie. He pulls off his tie an his shirt.  Julia doesn't move. The student peels off his shirt. Her eyes are drawn to a Superman tattooed on his shoulder. The student

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: insignia catches sight of Julia in the hallway. Her face turns bri immediately. She starts to laugh. He smiles at her. A bit flattered. Flirting.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Changing into something more formal. He holds up a pair of ripped jeans. Julia backs down the hallway. Still laughing. Embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was just using the ... (laughs) Really. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I'll forgive you this once. She quickly leaves. The blond student watches her go. A grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Julia walks out the back door. Stifling her laughter. Paul is talking with Guy on the lawn. Julia SNAPS a picture of them toget her film, and notices ...

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Sweet and innocent. Sitting on a bench. Motionless. Julia walks towards her. The little girl is staring across the lawn a shed. Transfixed. A group of children are playing on the grass it. The girl becomes aware of Julia's presence and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You sitting here all by yourself? The girl slowly nods "Yes." JULIA (cont'd) Don't you want to play with the other kids? The girls shakes her head "No."  JULIA (cont'd) Want me to leave you alone? The girl shakes her head "No." More silence. JULIA (cont'd) Want to mix this up and ask me something? The little girl notices the camera.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you taking pictures for Sam's family?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: No, I'm just (then) I'm a friend of Sam's. But I'm also a photographer. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Will you take a picture of me?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: So you won't forget me. I take pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Why would I forget you?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Because they're coming for me. A long beat. Julia sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Who is?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: The monsters.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What monsters?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: There. Behind the door. The girl points towards the pool shed. The rusted door of the shed is sli Just a crack.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Those other kids don't look too scared.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: They should be. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) So how come only you can see them?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Because I know they're real. I used to have a little brother, but they c him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now my parents say I never had a brother before. (pause) Soon ... my parents won't remember me either. Something about the girl's tone of voice is unnerving. As if she's resig this. A slight wind HISSES through the trees. The girl rises. GIRL (cont'd) I gotta go. They know I'm talking about them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Julia SNAPS a picture of the girl. JULIA (cont'd) Feel better? The girl stares  at her.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you scared of monsters?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I am. The girl turns and runs across the lawn. Julia is left sitting on the bench. She glances over at the pool shed a her camera and focuses on the door which is still cracked open.  She snaps the picture.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Julia and Paul are romantically entangled as they enter the apartment. A drunk. Kissing and frolicking. She strips off his jacket and tie. Paul a stops.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute (grabbing both sides of his shirt) This is a job for ... Paul rips his shirt wide open. Buttons popping everywhere. They both s Joining together, he guides her towards the bathroom. The wind gently HISSES on the balcony. Windchimes spinning.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A cloud of hot steam. The soothing rush of warm water running over tanne skin. Julia stands underneath the shower, her body relaxing into Paul's ches muscular arms encircling her body, his lips buried in her neck and shou eyes are shut. Her expression is calm.

dialogues.speaker: BLOND STUDENT
dialogues.text: Standing in the guest bedroom at Sam's house. Young and muscular. Bathed The tattoo  on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Her eyes still pressed closed. Smiling a little. Water continues rushing from the shower head, creating a HISS that eventu

dialogues.speaker: COAST HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: The setting sun blushes crimson across the rolling waves of the Pacific. along the highway is a RANGE ROVER, packed with luggage, headlights

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Paul sits behind the wheel. He's bopping and RAPPING with Sam to HI BLARES from the speakers. Very energized. Julia sits on the passenger side, leaning against the window, trying to music. Terry looks just as miserable. Finally, Julia turns off t A silent beat. The guys catch their girlfriends' expressions.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Sorry. Terry leans forward between the seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the cabin has electricity, right? And plumbing? Everything we need?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: So it has everything.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It has everything.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I hear a shoe about to drop.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Except a phone.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: BAM! There it is.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (scandalized) I need a phone. It's like family to me. Mom, Dad, my brother .... phone.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So you're roughing it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: The last time I tried to rough it, I was in therapy for a year. Why didn have a phone?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I guess she wanted to be left alone. At least until she got sick. Paul looks to her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This won't be too hard on you, will it? Staying at her place?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm enjoying this. Julia smiles at him. Paul smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good. He switches the radio back on and continues RAPPING with Sam. Julia and T stare straight ahead, ears pounding. This is turning into a LON

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Paul's Range Rover makes its way down a long, winding road. The Rover' illuminate the woods lining the road on both sides.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: The inside of the Range Rover is dark. Only the faint glow from the das provides any ambient illumination. Sam and Terry are snuggled toge back seat. Everything is quiet. Julia is thinking. Finally, she breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Do you believe in monsters? A beat. Everyone else in the car trades looks.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We've been in the car too long.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm just  asking.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Like what? The Boogeyman?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: The Boogeyman. The thing under the bed. The monster hiding in the closet

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What made you think of that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: A little girl at Sam's house. She was convinced there was a monster try her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're saying you believe her? Julia is suddenly on the spot. She backtracks.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Of course I don't. There are no monsters. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sure there are. Ted Bundy. Son of Sam. Ed Gein.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Who was Ed Gein?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He was a mass murderer. This old hermit who'd kill people and take the wanted. Heads. Livers. Intestines. Sex organs.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Why did he use the parts for?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Everything. The police found a skull that was used for a soup bowl. Faces and mounted like hunting trophies on the wall. Bones were use furniture.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He also wore their skin. Like clothes. Terry recoils into her seat. Grossed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I asked.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You wanted proof. There it is.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But it's not like he's a monster under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So why are kids afraid of that?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Because they live in a completely different world than we do. (then) Think about it. Why do kids pick up on things that we can't? ... Bumps in footsteps in the hallway? ... A thumping inside their clo

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Overactive imagination.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Wrong. Perfect awareness. (beat) Kids have a perfect awareness of everything around them. Every sound.  shadow. Everything gets quiet. SAM (cont'd) The Boogeyman could be real. So could monsters. Just because you've nev doesn't mean they aren't there. Silence. The car engine purrs softly. This is starting to make sense. spooky.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: All right. I'm creeped out. But my bullshit alarm is going off.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You just can't handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Because it's bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Serial killers aside, my take on this subject is very simple. If I don't picture of it -- it's not real.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Okay, is this conversation like a radio station? Can we just change the Because personally, I'd like to get to sleep tonight. Terry has just finished saying these words, when --

dialogues.speaker: DARK.
dialogues.text: have a channel?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIST
dialogues.text: Paul SLAMS on the brakes. Too late.

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: throwing the shape into a ditch at the side of the road. The Range Rover swerves and comes to a SQUEALING HALT.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Everyone catches their breath. A moment of dead silence.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (cont'd) Everyone  okay?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (nods) We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think it was a dog. Julia unlocks her door.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: We'd better check the car.  She steps out of the Rover. The others follow.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The hazard lights are switched on. Paul walks around to the front of The bumper is dented.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look at that. There's a couple thousand dollars out of my wallet.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You can probably get someone to pop it back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sure. For a couple hundred dollars. Sam looks down the road. He can barely make out a large form resting lif ditch. He starts walking towards it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your car, Paul ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (begrudging) Yeah, well. Shit happens. The conversation becomes distant as Sam walks slowly up the r past the yellow flashing HAZARD LIGHTS which CLICK rhythmically . click, click Sam approaches the ditch. Darkness is all around. wee. Click ... click ... click ... He kneels down alongside the body of the animal. Very little is visible except for its dark, mangled form sprawled across the dirt. Sam picks up a stick and pokes at the body. Nothing happens. He pokes at the corpse again. The hind legs of the corpse suddenly twitch. A reflex action. Sam leaps life nearly scared out of him.  A flap of hairless skin slides away from one of the animal's hind l leans forward to get a better look, becoming simultaneously repulsed an

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey guys!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Take a look at this.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Is ita dog? Sam glances at the dead corpse and back to his friends again. He looks s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. The rest of the group moves down the road. A weird unease has started to Paul and Julia kneel down in front of the corpse. It's almost unrecogniz darkness smothering the road keeps them from getting a handle on a body's features.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It looks like a dog to me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Did you see the leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it? Sam takes the stick and gently pushes away the flap of torn skin for a The group leans forward. A deep bleeding wound has been exposed. Through the torn flesh and blood charcoal skin, the group can see bones flashing into the moonlight intermingled with the animal's skeleton are ...

dialogues.speaker: PIECES OF METAL
dialogues.text: Glittering and clean. A series of connected stainless steel threads and that have grown together.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ever seen anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It looks like steel. Like someone put steel into its body.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't think it was put in there. It looks like it grew that way.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: That's impossible. What kind of animal has steel in its skeleton Terry steps forward tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Are you sure it's dead?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Come on, honey. It's a dog. Not a zombie.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Julia? Where's your camera?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It's in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it. Paul races back to the Range Rover and opens the passenger door. camera. Julia takes a step back into the middle of the trees, creating a soft HISSING noise as shadows. Paul returns and hands the camera to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You want to turn it over?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: road. He withdraws Julia's The wind is sifting through the the branches dance and twist in the  I'm not touching it. Sam kneels down. He points the camera and shoots. The camera flash cuts through the darkness and falls upon the corpse fora millisecond of clarity. Twisted metal. Skin. Appendages. Madness. Both of the young men stand frozen, thunderstruck, staring down at th shape in front of them. A long period of amazed silence follows.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That's wrong. That's all wrong. Paul shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a dog.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (stunned) What were those things coming out of its back? Paul starts recoiling. His stomach is getting weak.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's not a dog. The cool summer wind WHISTLES through the trees around them.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (sickened) That doesn't even make sense.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Paul ... Paul looks over at her. JULIA (cont'd) Let's get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We need some flashlights.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (hushed) Screw the flashlights.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dude. We're outta here. Julia and Paul walk briskly to the Range Rover. Sam and Terry follow the back over their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What the hell is it?!  Paul tosses the camera into the Rover's back seat. He SLAMS the door shut the front passenger door. A soft THUMPING from the woods. Almost like footsteps.

She moves to the mirror, washes her hands, and retrieves her purse. Water DRIPS from one of the leaky pipes in the bathroom while the flu over the mirror CRACKLES softly. Julia is about to brush her hair, something unnerves her. She cocks her head slightly. A feeling. She turns around and checks out the bathroom. The doors to the stal closed shut. Empty and quiet. She starts brushing her hair. A few moments pass. Then, she stops an the water DRIPPING from the pipe. Julia turns back around and looks bathroom.  One of the stall doors all the way at the end is now slightly open. Just enough to reveal a patch of darkness and gloom within. The sound of water dripping abruptly stops. Silence follows. Julia looks like she's about to crawl out of her skin. She quickly sh brush back into her purse and leaves.

The cars are empty. Sidewalk litter dances in the wind.

She looks walk-in closet across the room. The closet door is slightly open. Just a crack. Not enough to provide any of what lies within, but just enough for something -- monsters in peek out. Julia stares at the closet. Spooked. She knows better, but it's dark and fears are taking control.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Stupid. She gets out of bed and tiptoes to the closet, shutting the door. Then sh into bed.  Smiling to herself, she goes to sleep.

dialogues.text: whisper) Paul? Her hand finds nothing but sheets and empty space. There's nobody there. turns to locate her boyfriend. But he's gone. She tries to switch on the light. CLICK. The light stays off. She tries again. CLICK. Nothing happens. Then, she hears it. A faint sound. Almost like a SHUFFLING. The sound of dragging itself lightly across the floor to the edge of t Julia's throat has gone dry. Carefully, she creeps towards Paul's side checks the floor. There is nothing in sight. The only sign of movement are the shado trees outside. There is only one place left to look. Julia cautiously steps down to th Sinking down on her knees, she gently lifts up the dust ruffle and loo inky darkness underneath the bed. The space is empty. Julia drops the dust ruffle and sits up, GASPING.

dialogues.text: But I really did hear something. books into another

dialogues.text: That's an understatement. I have a sinking feeling that sex is out question for this trip.  This sparks something in Julia. She hesitates, looking through an ope where Paul can be seen packing some clothes. Julia speaks to Terry i

dialogues.text: Julia is closet wide open and I'm not upset That upsets me. left alone with her own puzzled walking down the hallway. She happens to pass the bathro is slightly open.

dialogues.text: It's okay. I  wasn't looking.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well damn, Julia. Your monster isn't just noisy, he's also inconside He kisses her on the cheek and takes off. Julia stands alone in the emp chill running down her spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slowly creaks open. Julia stands in the doorway, surveying the c cluttered and claustrophobic space despite its size. Clothes draped Cardboard boxes stacked on shelves. Shadows. Julia moves inside and pulls a string hanging from a light bulb which switch. Tick-tick. The bulb stays dark. She tries again. Tick-tick. The light still won't come on.  Julia carefully looks through some of the clothes. Nothing. She kneels do the floor. A long CREAKING behind her. The natural light fades. Julia looks over her shoulder, a bit skittish, as the closet door eas towards the doorjamb. But there's nobody there. Just the faintest hin Julia keeps searching through the clutter. Moving shoes and boxes out Searching. Then, she spots something glittering in the ribbon of light coming from t doorway. A small object resting in the corner. Julia reaches down an

dialogues.speaker: METAL ...
dialogues.text: Small and intricate with erratic markings. Twisted and strangely or shape and texture of the metal is almost completely alien. Julia holds the metal into the light. Extremely curious. Behind her, a sh CRASH. Julia SCREAMS, dropping the object and whirling around as a car SMASHES down behind her. Tumbling from one of the shelves above. Old s across the floor. Julia catches her breath. Heart pounding. On the floor, the metal object sparkles in the light. A draft HISSES th open closet door.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The Range Rover races down the empty road.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Julia sits behind the wheel. Her eyes intense. She looks over at the seat where both her purse and the metal object are located.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Range Rover streaks out of the woods towards Santa Mira.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia walks up the front steps leading to the library -- a weathered bui overlooks the town square. A banner hangs over the front entrance.

dialogues.speaker: READING ROOM
dialogues.text: The stacks are deserted and still. Julia sits at a reading table, flippi book, surrounded by long rows of bookshelves.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Julia flips from page to page, allowing momentary glimpses of various vampires, werewolves, witches, a ghastly thing crawling out from un maiden's bed.

dialogues.speaker: ON JULIA
dialogues.text: as she puts down the book and grabs another from a stack on the table it and starts paging through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Julia finds a drawing of a sleeping child. Just beyond the bed is an door, the horrid face a MONSTER watching the child from within. Julia shivers down to her soul. A familiar feeling of late. A slight SQUEAKING catches her attention. She looks across the rea find

dialogues.speaker: A YOUNG BOY
dialogues.text: Ten years old. Tow-haired. Sitting a few tables away but almost directly her. He's wearing a Superman shirt. He smiles timidly and waves. Julia waves back. A THUMP behind her. Julia turns and looks over her shoulder. She barely ofa shadow slipping across the wall in the stacks. The SCRAPING of chair legs against the cold floor. Julia looks back towar BOY was sitting. The chair is pushed back and empty. Another THUMPING in the stacks. Then silence. A feeling of anxiety washes over Julia as she grabs some of the books

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: It's getting dark. Moonshadows shift across the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Soft rock seeps from a pair of portable compact disc player speakers. Pa lid of grass and some zigzag papers and starts to roll a joint. looks pretty toasted. Cardboard boxes and CANDLES are everywhere. Sam is sitting off to himself. He's still drawing on his pad. Julia is r the books from the library.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (takes a hit) Monsters. Symbols and dream images. Now you see, I don't agree with think everything has some kind of physical representation. Peop come up with this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You did a good job last night.  Julia hands him the metal object from the closet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: And this? What do you make of this?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where'd you find it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: In the closet you didn't leave open.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What's she talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (wearisome) My girlfriend believes in the Boogeyman.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I never said it was the Boogeyman. Maybe it's some primeval energy that c response in human beings. This could be the physical representation o energy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Julia. It's piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I disagree. Julia turns hopefully to Terry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It's the physical representation of a piece of shit. Pot-induced laughter. Julia takes back the object.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You're not being objective about this. Have either of you ever been Really scared?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm scared right now that you've smoked too much.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Paul ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Okay. Sure. I've been really scared.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Like when? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe when we hit the dog. Sam looks unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You mean  this? Sam tosses his sketch pad into the center of the floor. Everyone leans f getting a good look at Sam's detailed drawing of --

dialogues.speaker: THE ANIMAL LEG
dialogues.text: Completely fleshed out with distinct mechanical parts hinged into fl Almost as accurate as a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (cont'd) That thing we hit on the road. It wasn't a dog. It wasn't some primeval either. (then) It was a monster.  Julia picks up the drawing as Paul peers over her shoulder. The picture particularly unsettling in the flickering firelight. It almost looks alive.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: It's late. The fire is dwindling. Terry and Sam have both passed out. Ju on the floor, staring at Sam's drawing while resting in Paul's l

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I can't believe Sam drew this.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can. He's been acting like a freak.  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You think we could've been wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: About the dog. Maybe the next day when Sam and I went back to the road . found the wrong body.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can we drop this? Please?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I just want to know ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (clipped) Stop.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I just want to know what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing's going on. Here, give me the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm not done yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hands are shaking. Come on, Julia. Give yourself a break. She hands the drawing pad to him. Paul puts it on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: We need to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Just relax. Paul begins stroking her hair. Gently and repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Just fora minute.  Julia looks really tired. She closes her eyes for a moment as Paul's breathing fills the room. The she opens them, turns her head and gazes at

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT ...
dialogues.text: Sitting ina chair. Smoking a cigarette. Smiling down at her. She cranks her head and looks deeply into her boyfriend's eyes. He smirk strokes her hair. JULIA (cont'd) Nice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (soft) You're tired.  Go to sleep. Her breathing becomes more steady. In the distance, a SOUND begins to permeate the cabin

dialogues.speaker: MACHINES ...
dialogues.text: Grinding and drumming like the churning of a large factory. noise, drifting over ...

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Quick FLASHES OF IMAGES which are strung together: (a) A turbine driven by a cloud of pumping steam. A calming and soothing  (b) The Superman tattoo on the Blond Student's shoulder. (c) A Doberman running across a road. (d) A man limping along wearing leg braces and using steel crutches (e) A woman's hands slipping over a young man's bare chest. (f) A back brace being locked into place.

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: The stall door at the far end of the bathroom eases open.

dialogues.speaker: THERE IS NO
dialogues.text: SOUND except for the HUMMING OF MACHINES. Julia stumbles through the snake pit. MENTAL PATIENTS stagger around her them are dressed like homeless people. Staring into space. Bodies gnawing on their fingers. Lying in their own urine. Julia looks skyward towards a SCREEN that doubles for a ceiling. Dark standing on the screen, looking down at them. A pair of ORDERLIES gently take Julia's arm and lead her out of the Julia looks at the wall as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shadows move across the wall. Almost like ripples in wate

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Blood trickles down over the Superman tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Clawed fingers slide around the open stall door.

dialogues.speaker: A HOMELESS
dialogues.text: PERSON is having a seizure. Propped against the wall. Sha horribly. His head and body are entirely covered with braces that form a met exoskeleton.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: A gynecology exam. A woman's legs are held open by stirrups. A pair o protected by rubber gloves cruelly insert a large alien-looking METAL which is nothing but sharp tentacles and angles -- between the leg

dialogues.speaker: SCREAMING FACE
dialogues.text: A woman shrieking through rotting teeth and blood.

dialogues.speaker: SURGICAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Julia steps into the surgical room. The LITTLE GIRL from Sam's party is resting on a gurney. Her small body i down with metal bands. Her blonde curls draped over the edge. Her e staring at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FOREHEAD.
dialogues.text: Julia tries to scream. No sound comes out. The shears close. Several drops of BLOOD ... then a BLONDE CURL ... hit the tile floor. The SOUND OF THE MACHINES is interrupted by GLASS BREAKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIVING ROOm - NIGHT Julia lurches awake. Paul and Terry are lying immobile on the floor. Hundreds of candles have throughout the room, bathing the cabin in a dull amber glow.  There is NO SOUND. Julia starts to rise to her feet. Her fingers graze something sharp. She snatches her fingers away from ...

dialogues.speaker: GLASS ...
dialogues.text: Julia discovers a small ribbon of blood trickling from her index finger. it, and notices -- SAM ... Sitting behind the couch. His eyes are intense as he erases something fr drawing pad. Julia walks around him until she can see the sketch.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA'S PORTRAIT.
dialogues.text: Sam erases the picture, working from the shoulders up. There is still NO SOUND. Julia is dumbfounded. She hears a slight noise coming from somewhe cabin. A small HISSING sound. Soft and unobtrusive. Julia looks around. The sound seemed to come from behind her. But the in the room. Her friends are still asleep. Sam is concentrating drawing. More HISSING. Unmistakable this time. A diminutive SCRAPING, almost lik raking on icy glass, slithering out from a darkened hallway. She moves towards the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia creeps into the hallway until she can barely see the rows of bed All of them are closed shut. The SCRAPING sound rises up again. Much closer. Behind one of the bedr Beckoning. Julia reaches out for the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The door opens. Julia's stomach rises into her throat. Terror floods her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia's body goes rigid. She can't force herself to move.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORPSE INSIDE IS STILL HIDDEN.
dialogues.text: As if drawn by some alien force, Julia moves to the bed. Her entire body She reaches out and carefully peels back the plastic. Resting within the body bag is THE LITTLE GIRL. Eyes puffed shut. Hair s blood. Her skin is livid. Her face is ghostly white and smeared with gore. Julia is frozen in place. Heart pounding. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Julia is startled awake and groggily looks around the room. Paul a still in the process of getting up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look who's up. (smiles) You sleep well? Julia STARES back. She looks pretty freaked. PAUL (cont'd)  Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I didn't sleep well either. I dreamt that all these cockroaches were eat

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You want to trade? Right before I woke up, my head exploded and all t came out.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Where's Sam?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Probably went to bed. Terry nods as  she rises to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I need a hairbrush. And a facial. She stumbles into the hallway. Paul turns to Julia.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You had nightmares too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Worst ones I've had in a long time. I thought I was hallucinating. Paul winces and rubs his temples. JULIA (cont'd)  What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Headache. I'll be fine. Terry briskly walks out the hallway. She looks alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You guys. Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The group walks towards one of the bedroom doors.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It's Sam. I  can't get the door open. Paul tries the doorknob. The door won't budge. Paul KNOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sam, open up. No answer. He POUNDS harder. PAUL (cont'd) Sam?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He won't answer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Maybe he can't  answer. Paul shoves hard against the door. But it still won't give.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What about the bathroom door? It connects to your room.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I tried it. It's locked. Paul turns the doorknob and throws all his weight against the door, tryi to bust it down. No such luck.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (voice rising)  Sam? He tries again and again. WHOOMPH! .... WHOOMPH! .... WHOOMPH! The door inches open. Just a crack.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (cont'd) Help me out with this. Paul and Julia push on the door, forcing it wider.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Paul struggles through the aperture, slipping underneath a mattress that placed against the door, and stumbles into the room.  THE BEDROOM IS A DISASTER AREA. Clothes and smashed glass cover the floor. Mirrors have been shattere the furniture and portions of the bed have been piled in fron door, creating an almost impassible barricade. The window billowing in the breeze. Julia and Terry make their way into the room. Stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Careful of the glass. Don't step on it. Total silence. The group stares at the room. Taking it in.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What happened? is wide open, the curtains Trying to comprehend it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frozen) You got me.

dialogues.speaker: WALKING TRAIL
dialogues.text: Paul and Terry are walking along the trail. Searching.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (calling) Sam? No reply. Her words sound hollow in the empty forest as they keep movin behind huge pine trees that obscure them from view. A soft breeze  rises up and HISSES through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Julia is cleaning the mess in the room. She's just finished tossin shards of broken glass into a garbage bag when she FLINCHES and dra finger back. The finger has a scab on it. Exactly where she cut it in the dream. Drie the wound.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Terry looks beside herself. Paul and Julia are seated.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: He must have gotten out through the window. That's the only thing I c

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: We have to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You looked everywhere?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Everywhere near the cabin. But we can't cover every square inch of forest

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He might be sick. He might need help.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: TI can't  understand why he'd do something like this.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He was acting nuts. Really nuts.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (impatient) I need a phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wait. I've got my cell. Paul fishes the cell phone out of his pocket. He hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: RINGS.
dialogues.text: Almost on cue. Terry glances over at her friends,

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat) Julia and Paul sit up in their seats.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (cont'd) Where are you? ... No, where are you? ... (beat) How did you get there? ... then clicks the receiver.  Terry hurriedly grabs a pen. She starts writing on a pad. TERRY (cont'd) Just a minute. I'm writing it down. Market Street. The Ramada. I think I it is. (beat) Sam, what's going on? What happened? ... (then) Sam? ... SAM? She hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where is  he?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I don't know. He wants me to meet him. My brother has an apartment up t out of town, but I have a spare key. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You still want to call the police? I guess I could stay there. He's  Silence. Terry doesn't respond to this. Outside an open window, the WIND HISSES through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty bus station consisting of a single room with a CLERK sitting front desk. Julia and Paul are sitting on a pair of chairs, waiting p Terry is using a phone booth outside. She hangs up and walks into the de

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Did you get his parents?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It was the  wrong number.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Didn't Sam give you that number?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Maybe I wrote it down wrong. Terry winces a bit. She massages her legs.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: My legs are killing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want us to drive you?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Nah. You have to stick around for the movers. I'll be fine. The bus arrives in front of the depot. TERRY (cont'd) There's my ride. Terry grabs her suitcase. Julia hands her a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: This is Paul's cell number. You call us. Let us know what happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need to talk to him. Don't call the police or anything until I've to do that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Terry hugs Julia. Paul gives her a quick kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Remember. Call

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I will. Carrying her suitcase, Terry backs toward the door, smiling sadly at J as she opens it. TERRY (cont'd) It'll be okay. Everything's okay. Her voice resonates with desperate hope rather than confidence. She depot. Paul places his arms around Julia as they watch the bus leave the station smoke.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Julia is cleaning up. She kneels down and picks up some of the mel and beer  bottles. Paul walks into room holding a broken picture frame.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I talked to the movers.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Why didn't they show up?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The company has no record of the order. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Are they coming now?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It'll take them a while to work us into the schedule -- get a van out her everything.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhausted) Shit. Paul holds out the mangled frame.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I also found this in the guest bedroom. Sam knocked one of the packing This was inside. Julia takes a look at the frame. It's the same picture from her room of her mother. The broken glass has torn the photograph. PAUL (cont'd) I wasn't sure if you wanted to keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I've got one. Beat. JULIA (cont'd) You know this is the only picture I have of my mother? (beat) She was always taking pictures of us, but we never got any of her. (emotional) If I didn't have this, I couldn't prove that I had a mother.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's not  true. Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm so worried about Sam. Julia drowns in her thoughts. Paul touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let's get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (smiles) Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll get my keys. Paul walks out. Julia places the frame on the coffee table. She notices something on the floor. Julia squints. It's a small objec the corner ++. almost hidden from view. Julia reaches into the shado up... ANOTHER PIECE OF METAL WITH STRANGE MARKINGS. EXACTLY LIKE THE ONE FROM THE CLOSET. Julia stares at the object in her palm. Surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Where are these coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warm summer afternoon. The entire town has congragated in a park with breathtaking view of the ocean. MUSIC and NOISE. A huge banner draped over the

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATES THE 45TH ANNUAL FOUNDER'S DAY FESTIVAL
dialogues.text: Julia navigates her way past the booths and thrill rides that have been e lawn. She watches some passersby. JULIA'S POV ... as A MOTHER talks on a cell phone while her six year-old at her sleeve. Trying to get her attention. The mother keeps pus child away as she talks. Julia observes this scene until she hears ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your mother. Julia steps out of the crowd. Searches for the voice.

dialogues.speaker: A HOMELESS
dialogues.text: WOMAN is shadowing a COLLEGE-AGE GIRL walking with her bo They're trying to ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'm your mother ... I'm your mother ... I'm your mother ... The couple walks faster. The Homeless Woman is left behind.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS
dialogues.text: WOMAN (cont'd) (futile) I'm your mother Julia stares helplessly. EXT. PARK -вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: CAROUSEL
dialogues.text: Spinning merrily in the center of the park. Bright lights. Loud CA Young kids and teenagers occupy the horses and benches. Julia slowly walks towards the carousel, snapping pictures of the chil whirling lights. Behind her, the sound of a SCREAMING CHILD rises music and laughter. She turns and finds a two year old BABY sitting father's shoulders, crying and pointing at --

dialogues.speaker: BOY ...
dialogues.text: Wearing his blue Superman shirt. He's sitting on a swing set by himse alone. He makes eye contact with Julia. Waves timidly. She smiles at him and

dialogues.speaker: CAROUSEL
dialogues.text: Gears turning. The poles spearing the horses rising and falling into the platform rotating near the grass. The CALLIOPE MUSIC becomes the HUMMING of MACHINES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia is wandering through a maze of shooting galleries. She sear the crowds of teenagers and children at the booths. Finally, she loc PAUL ... Approaching her with a large Teddy Bear under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Basketball toss. I won this for you. Julia smiles at the bear.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You sure you  want to give him up?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (nice smile) I think he'd crowd my Barbie collection. Julia kisses him. He kisses her back and winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Head still hurts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Need some aspirin?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Already took some. I'll be okay. Paul notices that they've wandered into a row of PSYCHIC and TAROT CAR PAUL (cont'd) Hey, look. Want to get your palm read?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: As long as you're feeling up to it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I am. Come  on. Julia spots another booth with a sign overhead: "THE PAST THROUGH POS

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Just a minute. You go to the palm reader. I want to check out this one.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: "The past through possessions?" (unimpressed) Scam city.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: And palm reading isn't? She's got him  there.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: All right. I'll meet you over there.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Thanks. She kisses him quickly. They split up.

dialogues.speaker: READER'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: Paul approaches the booth. An African-American woman in her mid-forties, counter. Loose

dialogues.speaker: TESS,
dialogues.text: sits behind the and upbeat. Wearing more colors in her clothing than eve could provide.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can you read my palm? She grins.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: You got five bucks?

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Julia walks to the front counter of the booth. A pair of women are sitting behind the counter, but the one who sticks ou ROSEMARY, sixty, psychic and clairvoyant. She wears a purple kaftan which her weakness for ice cream and cookies.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: Can we help you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You can tell me things just by holding something of mine. Right?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. I have a perfect track record. I found two missing children spring of '74, and helped the state police catch a murderer in '81.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Wow. That's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sourly) My grandchildren aren't quite as impressed. (a little brighter) What did you want me to look at? Julia reaches into her pocket and gently places something on the counte Rosemary.

dialogues.speaker: READER'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: Tess takes Paul's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's kinda stupid. But I sorta wanted to know about my Dad. If I sho

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: (knowingly) You and your father don't get along.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Something  happened?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My parents got divorced when I was sixteen. I got into a fight with him. stuff. He bows his head a little. A tough subject for him.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Let's take a look ... Tess cocks her head a little to the side. She looks confused. TESS (cont'd) (soft) I'll be damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Well kid, you might be the first person to make me hang up my fortune t degree. Usually the palm makes sense, and this one doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: According to this, you don't exist. OFF Paul, his face turning white.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Rosemary handles one of the metal objects, watches her as she goes through this ritual.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: This is interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Let me guess. They came from a vacuum cleaner, Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: Machines. turning it over in her palm. Julia right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: This came from a machine. But not a household appliance.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Where did it come from? Rosemary turns the object over in her palm. Over and over.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: Something that was alive. Julia leans forward in her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you just said it came from a machine.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So how can a machine be alive?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: I don't make the news. I just report it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I found the larger one inside of a closet. Do you know how it got the Rosemary continues meditating. Turning the object over between he Staring at it. Gradually, she falls into a trance. Her breathing slows.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: We shed our parts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: And our skin.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. What are you talking about?  Rosemary is oblivious to anything around her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: But they need to be replaced. Some of the parts we can find. (beat) Others need to be harvested. The other PSYCHIC seated next to Rosemary throws her a curious glan counts up some money. ROSEMARY (cont'd) We'll wait on the side of the road. Until one of the machines come. (beat)  One of us will be sacrificed. skins are inside. (softer) We can use their parts. Paul walks up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Julia? She motions for him to be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: We stopped the machine. But there are more of the That will stop the machine. Then we can take whatever skins than we thought ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia. Let's take off.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: We must wait. More of us are needed to capture them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What's she talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Wait just a minute. Please.  Beat. The objects continue turning in her hand ... and turning ... and turn turning

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: There are more of us now. We've surrounded them. But they're leaving too

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Julia? В». and turning ...

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: We'll follow them. We'll watch them. (beat)  We'll take them as the need for parts becomes necessary ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (louder) Julia? The wind gently HISSES through the booth's tent.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMARY
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll only take one ... (beat) Maybe we'll take another ... and another ... and another ... and anot A sudden gust of wind rises through the tent as ...

dialogues.speaker: PITCH BLACK.
dialogues.text: The sound of mumbling and confusion seethes from the crowd. Julia rise chair. Paul takes her into her arms as CHILDREN can be heard CRY throughout the park. Above them, the wind HISSES through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Julia sits on the porch. Paul is stretched out on the grass looking up

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So the power went out. That doesn't mean anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what she said?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: She was talking about the accident. The night you hit that thing on the r about that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Julia, a psychic tells you some random shit and then lets YOU make it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: She said it was waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure. An animal was waiting for us to come along and run it down. explanation? Rotten home life? Was it taking Prozac?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It wanted to stop the car.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Something about needing parts.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If it needed parts, it shouldn't have committed suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said there were more of them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who cares what she said? It doesn't mean anything.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But it's not just that. Julia's voice becomes soft. As if she were telling a secret. JULIA (cont'd) I've also had this feeling. Ever since Sam disappeared. I can't shake i

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I feel like something's missing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Something?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's on the tip of my tongue. that morning, something's not right. Like here

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right. Sam.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I just feel like ever since we woke up there's someone who should be  It's not Sam. (then) Did that palm reader say anything strange to you. Paul hesitates. He looks back at the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Can I use your phone?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Anything at all?  A traditional home. The phone rings and Connor comes charging down the answers it.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Julia is sitting on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Connor. It's Julia.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought you were someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to hear your voice too.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: You having fun?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (understated) Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: I got my PSAT's back. 720 verbal. 690 math. You think that's good enough Berkeley?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You'll get in. Listen, is Dad there?

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well could you leave him a message?

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Tell him that the movers didn't come, so I'll be here a few more days. I have some stuff of Mom's that he might want.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Don't forget.

dialogues.speaker: CONNOR
dialogues.text: Jesus. Show a little faith. When have I ever forgotten something? INT. DARKROOM вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A piece of developing paper is slipped into the tray basin. Julia gently rocks the basin back and forth. A picture starts to manif paper.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Paul splashes his face with water. He looks worse than he did the night Weaker. He grabs some aspirin from the medicine cabinet. INT. DARKROOM вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Julia leans forward to get a better view of the developing picture. A slowly forming -- carousel horses, the vague outlines of poles a

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Paul is shirtless and doing one-armed push-ups. His muscles churn rises and falls like a piston. INT. DARKROOM вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The picture has come into view. The carousel. The children laughing as th horses. And something else ... An irregularity. A dark form in the center of the carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's arm as he does push-ups, sweat beading on his bice rippling. The SOUND of MACHINES pulsates and segues into ... INT. DARKROOM вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Julia takes the  picture out of the developing basin.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Paul is sitting on the couch, wearing a UCLA cross country tank top and t shoes. Julia enters from the basement. She's carrying a stack of devel pictures.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Paul, you have to see this. The picture came out, but there's something strange in the middle of it. Just like the other one of the shed. He looks at the  picture.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Looks like someone on the carousel.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But there's no features. It's like a shadow.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So there wasn't enough light. Paul rubs his forehead. Julia is genuinely concerned.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My head feels worse.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Maybe you should lie down.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I have to go running.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Of course I do. Your body's like a machine. It needs upkeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not when you're physically ill.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Paul ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll be okay. (about the picture) Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Not exactly. (beat) When I saw this picture, I decided to look at the other one. Just for com sake.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So? Julia takes out another photograph.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I pulled this one by mistake. The picture of that little girl from the She hands him the picture.  JULIA (cont'd) Look. Paul's face collapses into slack disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO. VANISHED.
dialogues.text: Paul turns to Julia as she looks into his eyes with a mixture of fear a apprehension. JULIA (cont'd) What's going on? This time, he doesn't have an answer.

dialogues.speaker: WALKING TRAIL
dialogues.text: Murky and still. A few shafts of sunlight permeate the gloom. Paul is jogging along the trail, keeping a steady pace, the sounds of the around him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The trail snakes towards a wooden bridge that spans over a tricklin runs across, the soles of his sneakers SLAPPING on creaking wo He moves deeper into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIL
dialogues.text: A lonely part of the woods where almost all the daylight is blocked out trees.  Paul jogs along the trail when he slows to a halt, sweaty and out of brea is pale. His limbs are shivering. Paul cradles his head, shutting suffering from obvious pain.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (very soft) Oh God .... make it stop ... He starts walking forward again. Very slowly. A slight TINKLING sound as he kicks something at his feet. His eye as he looks down ...

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIL. ALMOST LIKE NUTS AND BOLTS, BUT ALIEN IN THEIR
dialogues.text: Paul reaches down and picks one of the bolts up. Studies it. He keeps following more pieces of metal that lead off the footpath.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A darker spot enclosed by pine trees. A few birds are singing overhead. Paul enters the forest, pushing back branches, following the trail of dis until he freezes ... his eyes staring directly ahead at ...

dialogues.speaker: SKIN ...
dialogues.text: Hanging from branches. Scattered on the ground. Like the skin of a sna been shed. Paul is completely unsettled. He kneels down, picking up a flap o the ground, peeling it away from a steel ROD dripping with oozing sl up. It's still black in color but almost transparent in the murky The wind HISSES through the trees, mussing Paul's hair. Paul drops the piece of skin on the ground. The birds abruptly stop singing in unison. The WIND CEASES. Paul looks around the forest. The sudden quiet has got him spooked. legs stiffen. Paul can't even bring himself to move or breathe

dialogues.speaker: DROPS ON HIS SHOULDER ...
dialogues.text: Paul freaks and whirls around, grabbing his shoulder to find

dialogues.speaker: A PIECE OF SKIN
dialogues.text: Clinging to him. He rips it off and sprints for the footpath.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTPATH
dialogues.text: Paul sprints out of the forest, running with blinding speed and adrena doesn't look back. Behind him, the wind HISSES through the trees again.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Julia comes up from the basement. She hears COUGHING coming from the bat

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Julia enters the bathroom. Paul is retching and coughing into the toi plastered to his forehead. Pale as death. Shaking badly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Paul? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (feeble) Sick. She goes to him. Rubs his shoulders as he COUGHS again.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh baby ... Julia brushes the hair from his forehead. She freezes.  Just above his temple is a SCAB. No bigger than the head of an eraser. I the one on Julia's finger. JULIA (cont'd) Paul? Where did this come from?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: This scab. Julia runs her finger over the scab. Paul immediately reels from her tou shooting through his head, furious.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Julia is shocked by the severity of his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Paul holds his head tight. Almost near tears. Fighting pain.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just don't touch it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: How long has it been there?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ever since my head started to hurt.  (then) I think I'm hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What did you see?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Skin ... like it was shed ... and all of these metal pieces ... Julia is terribly concerned now. His description frightens her, bu maintains a visage of calm.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Do you want to see a doctor? I know there's one in Santa Mira.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see a doctor in Los Angeles. (then) Look, I want to get out of here, okay? Let's go home. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay. She squeezes his shoulder and walks into --

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Julia pulls out their duffle bags and suitcases.  Paul's cell phone RINGS on the table. Julia snatches up the phone and

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Hello? ... Yes? (then) Wait a minute .+. Slow down, I can't understand what you're saying ... Complete astonishment storms Julia's face. Paul wanders in.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It's Terry. Something went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: Gloomy and overcast. Storm clouds are brewing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: The Range Rover pulls down a crowded street.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Julia is sitting behind the wheel. Navigating traffic. Paul sits on the passenger side, leaning against the window, his face against the glass. Somber and weak.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE
dialogues.text: pressed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twisted remains of a car accident has brought everything to a nea Police are everywhere. An ambulance is parked along the curb, li flashing. Julia leans forward to get a better look.

dialogues.speaker: A TEEN ACCIDENT
dialogues.text: VICTIM presses a white towel against his thigh. Blood gus A huge metal ROD sticks out of his leg.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: The Range Rover moves past the shredded cars involved in the accident. Tw covers the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer rain is falling. THUNDER ROLLS overhead. The Rover pulls up to the sidewalk, directly in front of an extremely opu class house.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Julia turns to Paul who sits silently in the passenger seat. He doesn't

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Sure you don't want to come with me?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm too sick. I need to stay someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried about leaving you here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It's not like he'll disown me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And I really need him right now. More THUNDER. Julia kisses his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking the cell phone. You call me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: See a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I will. Paul opens the passenger door and steps out into the rain. the house. Then, she pulls away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: HEIGHTS RESIDENCE
dialogues.text: Julia watches him approach  A nice house. Large and affluent. The DOORBELL CHIMES. A few moments pass before a sullen FIGURE arrives at the front door and open, revealing ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: standing on the front porch. His wet hair plastered to his forehead, rain off his cheeks, his handsome face turned pallid and colorless. He manages a sheepish smile.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dad.  Standing at the door is a man in his mid-fifties, MR. LOOMIS. A severe pr soured and weathered face. He stares at Paul without any sign of Paul notices the slight. He presses onward. A bit haltingly. Still hop trying to connect. PAUL (cont'd) I was hoping we could talk ... (beat) I know we haven't done much of that recently, but still ... (beat) I was hoping. Beat.  PAUL (cont'd) I'm in a lot of trouble. I'm getting sick ... and I was hoping ... (beat) I was hoping you could help. Paul is having difficulty speaking. He's almost reduced to tears as he s cold, stinging rain. PAUL (cont'd) I want to come home. Please Dad. (desperate) Please let me come home.  A moment of silence. PAUL (cont'd) Please? His father stands steely eyed. His voice is icy and distant.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I don't know you. Paul is devastated. He can barely utter a sound.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm your son. Agonizing  beat.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS
dialogues.text: I don't have a son. (then) I don't know you. He slowly closes the door. Paul begins weeping openly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dad ... The door is shut in his face. Nothing can be heard except for the rai outside.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Julia is standing near the entrance. Waiting patiently. A figure across the street catches Julia's attention -- a HOMELESS MAN stumbling down the sidewalk, himself, shaking a rattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia? Julia turns around, searching, not immediately recognizing the figure approaches her -- It's Terry. But her once perfect appearance has become harsh and drawn. H hair has been colored dark brown. There are sagging circles under her e is colorless. She moves quickly. Nervously. Julia is  shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Terry? Terry's hands tremble.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came. You don't have any idea how scared I've been.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Why did you change your hair? Terry is about to answer when a BABY starts crying in the market. Fear t of her face.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: We can't stay here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Where are you parked?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: On the street.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Good. If we keep moving, they might have trouble tracking us. Terry takes Julia's arm and leads her out of the market.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: Terry is moving at a swift pace. She keeps looking back over her shoulder tries to keep up. Rain drenches them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? Where's Sam?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He's dead. This almost sends Julia reeling. Her mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's three things you should remember. Three things.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What happened to Sam?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: First, whenever you see a baby or a kid crying, keep moving. That's your warning.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Warning against who?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Second, they Children can sense them. can control anything electrical or mechanical. Lamps. Ca

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Terry, you're not making any sense.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Third -- they can change things. They can make you disappear.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I am telling you. (terrified) They took him.  They made him disappear. Julia stops walking. Speechless.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: A young COLLEGE STUDENT is typing on his powerbook, oblivious to the TRAN on the sidewalk, head buried in his knees, a sign at his feet re

dialogues.speaker: THE
dialogues.text: POWERBOOK. A soft WHIRRING noise seeping from the computer as the student types. The WHIRRING becomes the HUMMING OF MACHINES. The Range Rover appears on the street and moves past.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (v.0.)  They take away your identity. People stop remembering you. Your place in vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Julia is behind the wheel. Terry is devouring a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: That's how they get you. By making people not even care about you anymore

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Did you try Sam's parents? Did you get the right number this time?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: The number I called at the bus station was his parents.  (cryptic) We didn't hit a dog on the road.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: They switched bodies.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Who are "they?" A cult? Killers? Terry starts laughing to herself. Tears welling in her eyes. Hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You have no idea. No idea what you're dealing with. (then) They don't even belong here. They're like ... like machines. That's what Like machines with all this skin and moving parts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: They're machines?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Monsters. They're monsters, Julia. Julia stops at a light.

dialogues.speaker: A YOUNG GUY
